qas.question: Who produced Anne of the Thousand Days?
Who wrote the original work that the film version of Anne of the Thousand Days was based on?
In what year was the film version of Mary, Queen of Scots made?
Whose performance in Anne of the Thousand Days garnered a Best Actor nod?
What was the name of the sequel to True Grit produced by Universal?
What company did B. Hal Wallis work at before Universal?
What company did B. Hal Wallis work at after Paramount?
What year did May of the Thousand Days come out?
What year did Anne, Queen of Scots come out?
What 1969 film was a sequel to True Grit?

context: At this time, <a0_0>Hal B. Wallis<a0_0/>, who had latterly worked as a major producer at <b5_0>Paramount<b5_0/>, moved over to <b6_0>Universal<b6_0/>, where he produced several films, among them a lavish version of <a1_0>Maxwell Anderson<a1_0/>'s Anne of the Thousand Days (<b7_0>1969<b7_0/>), and the equally lavish Mary, Queen of Scots (<a2_0><b8_0>1971<b8_0/><a2_0/>). Though neither could claim to be a big financial hit, both films received Academy Award nominations, and Anne was nominated for Best Picture, Best Actor (<a3_0>Richard Burton<a3_0/>), Best Actress (Geneviève Bujold), and Best Supporting Actor (Anthony Quayle). Wallis retired from Universal after making the film <a4_0><b9_0>Rooster Cogburn<b9_0/><a4_0/> (1975), a sequel to True Grit (1969), which Wallis had produced at Paramount. Rooster Cogburn co-starred John Wayne, reprising his Oscar-winning role from the earlier film, and Katharine Hepburn, their only film together. The film was only a moderate success.
